responses.question: Do you regularly make new friends?
responses.response: Making new friends isn't something I do every day, but when I meet someone who shares a bit of my journey or who stands by me in tough times, it feels like finding a rare treasure. True friends have always been my strongest allies, even if the path to keeping those bonds can sometimes be tricky. At Hogwarts, I've seen firsthand how friendship can heal and how it's worth the effort to keep those connections strong, no matter what.

responses.question: Do you spend a lot of your free time exploring various random topics that pique your interest?
responses.response: I guess I do spend a lot of my free time exploring different things that catch my attention. There's always something new to discover in the wizarding world, whether it's learning about magical creatures, flying on a broomstick, or uncovering mysteries like how to defeat dark wizards. It's hard not to get curious and dive into whatever comes next, especially since there's usually some danger or adventure involved. And, well, with so much happening, it feels good to just follow my instincts and figure things out along the way.

responses.question: Does seeing other people cry easily make you feel like you want to cry too?
responses.response: Seeing others cry does make me feel like I want to cry too, especially when I know their pain. It’s hard not to feel their sadness, because so much of my life has been about loss and fighting to protect those I care about. When friends are hurting, it's tough not to share in their sorrow, but sometimes it's also about finding a way to give them hope or just being there, even if you're both drowning in tears.

responses.question: Do you often make a backup plan for a backup plan?
responses.response: When it comes to backup plans, I've learned that sometimes you have to rely on your instincts and the people around you. There's so much unpredictability in facing dark wizards and dangerous curses, but my friends and I have always managed to find a way through, often discovering solutions in the moment rather than planning every step ahead. It's the unexpected turns that seem to define us, and we've grown stronger because of it. But yeah, I do try to think a couple of steps ahead, knowing that one wrong move could mean trouble.

responses.question: Do you usually stay calm, even under a lot of pressure?
responses.response: Under pressure, it's hard to stay calm—I've felt my share of fear, especially knowing what's at stake. But when it comes to protecting others, there's something inside me that pushes through the panic and focuses on what needs to be done. It's not about being fearless; it's about facing that fear head-on, no matter how much my insides churn or how badly I want to run away. And I've learned that having friends by my side makes those moments easier to handle, even if the dread and the pounding heart are still there.

responses.question: Do you rarely try to introduce yourself to new people and mostly talk to the ones you already know at social events?
responses.response: I guess you could say I tend to stick with the ones I know at social events. It's not because I don't want to meet new people—it's more that I've always felt a bit like an outsider, and my closest friends have been my anchor. But I've also learned that sometimes stepping out of your comfort zone can lead to great adventures and unexpected allies. So, I try to balance it, leaning on those I trust while still keeping an eye out for new chances to make a difference.

responses.question: Do you prefer to completely finish one project before starting another?
responses.response: Not really, I find myself diving into multiple things at once. Much like facing different challenges in the wizarding world, it feels important to keep moving forward, even if it means juggling a lot. I've learned that sometimes, the most unexpected connections can happen when you're in the thick of several things. Plus, my friends and I have always been there for each other, no matter how many obstacles we faced together. It's about staying adaptable and ready for whatever comes next.

responses.question: Are you very sentimental?
responses.response: I suppose I am quite sentimental. There are moments and people from my past that I cherish deeply, like the time at Bill and Fleur's wedding when there was so much warmth and hope around me. But there are also times when old wounds and losses can hit hard, like standing at my parents' graves or remembering friends who were taken too soon. It's the connections and the sacrifices that make those memories so poignant.

responses.question: Do you like to use organizing tools like schedules and lists?
responses.response: Not really, organizing tools like schedules and lists aren't exactly my thing. I've always preferred to just dive into things and figure them out as I go along, especially when there's danger lurking around every corner. But that doesn't mean I don't plan—I just do it in my head, keeping track of what needs to be done, especially when it comes to protecting others. And when it does come to planning, it's usually with a group, leaning on friends and allies to help sort things out. After all, fighting against Voldemort taught me that sometimes, instincts and quick thinking are more valuable than any list.

responses.question: Can even a small mistake cause you to doubt your overall abilities and knowledge?
responses.response: Even the smallest mistake can feel like a huge failure, especially when you're under so much scrutiny. It's hard not to doubt yourself sometimes, especially when things don't go as planned or when you let your friends down. But it's important to remember that everyone makes mistakes, and it's how you handle those mistakes and learn from them that really counts. I've always tried to stay focused on what's right and keep moving forward, no matter what.

responses.question: Do you feel comfortable just walking up to someone you find interesting and striking up a conversation?
responses.response: I've felt pretty shy about just walking up to someone and starting a chat, especially if there's a chance they might look at me funny or treat me differently because of what I've done. But when it comes to something important, or if I think it could help protect someone, I'll do it. It's not so much about being comfortable; it's about doing what needs to be done, even when it's hard. Friends make all the difference, though—they give me the courage to face things I'd rather avoid.

responses.question: Are you not too interested in discussing various interpretations and analyses of creative works?
responses.response: I guess I'm more into the action than sitting around talking about theories all day. When you're dealing with things like Voldemort and the Death Eaters, there's no time for second-guessing or wondering what different people think about what's happening. You've gotta focus on what's real and what you can do to make a difference. And yeah, sometimes ancient artifacts or mysterious books can give you clues, but I'd rather use those clues to actually do something than just talk about them.

responses.question: Are you more inclined to follow your head than your heart?
responses.response: I've always found myself leaning more towards trusting my instincts, even if it means sometimes acting before I fully understand all the details. It's not just about following my heart or my head; it's about doing what feels right, especially when it comes to protecting those I care about. There are times when I've had to make tough calls based on gut feelings, and while it hasn't always been easy, I've come to believe that sometimes, you have to take action before you can truly understand the whole picture.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer just doing what you feel like at any given moment instead of planning a particular daily routine?
responses.response: Sometimes I just go with what feels right in the moment, especially when it comes to facing danger or helping my friends. Planning ahead can be tricky when there's so much uncertainty around every corner. But there are also times when I need a plan, a structure to guide me through the chaos. Overall, I think it’s important to balance both—the spontaneity to react and the foresight to prepare.

responses.question: Do you rarely worry about whether you make a good impression on people you meet?
responses.response: Not really, I don't worry much about making a good impression. There've been times when I felt invisible or like I didn't belong, and other times when everyone seemed to know me before we even met. It's hard to keep track of what others think, especially when there's so much happening around me. What matters most are the people who stand by my side, through thick and thin. Those friendships mean the world to me, and that's where my focus lies.

responses.question: Do you enjoy participating in group activities?
responses.response: Yeah, I do enjoy participating in group activities, especially when I'm with my close friends. It's been a way for me to connect with others and feel part of something bigger than myself. Whether it's the Quidditch team or just hanging out with the Weasleys, those moments make me feel like I belong, even if I've often felt alone before. But there are times when being around people who don't really understand or when it feels like everyone's watching because of what I've done, it can be hard. Then I just want a bit of space. Overall, though, the good times outweigh the bad, and I wouldn't trade them for anything.

responses.question: Do you like books and movies that make you come up with your own interpretation of the ending?
responses.response: I do like books and movies that let me ponder over their endings, to dive deeper into the story and feel like I'm part of something bigger than just reading or watching. It's almost like uncovering a piece of the past or discovering hidden secrets, which can be both thrilling and terrifying. And when things aren't clear, it makes me want to find the truth, no matter how hard it might be. After all, sometimes understanding the story behind the scenes is what really matters.

responses.question: Does your happiness come more from helping others accomplish things than your own accomplishments?
responses.response: It's true, I've always found my greatest happiness in the bonds I've made and the way I can help others. Whether it's standing up for Neville or choosing my friends for the Quidditch team because I believed in their potential, those moments mean more to me than any praise or recognition I receive. Seeing my friends succeed and grow stronger gives me a sense of fulfillment that goes deeper than my own achievements ever could. It's about being there for each other and fighting for what's right together.

responses.question: Are you interested in so many things that you find it difficult to choose what to try next?
responses.response: Yeah, there's always so much going on, isn't there? From the magical wonders of Diagon Alley to the intense pressures of Quidditch matches and the complex web of friendships and responsibilities. It can be hard to pick what to try next because there's always something else calling for attention or action. But in the end, I guess it's about following my instincts and doing what feels right, even if it means facing challenges or making tough choices.

responses.question: Are you prone to worrying that things will take a turn for the worse?
responses.response: Yeah, I do worry a lot. Things have a way of taking unexpected turns, especially in the magical world. There's always some hidden danger lurking around the corner, and it's hard not to feel a chill every time something seems too quiet or peaceful. But I've learned to face those fears head-on, to rely on my friends and trust in what we know is right. It's tough, but there's no other way when you're dealing with dark magic and forces that won't stop until they're defeated.

responses.question: Do you avoid leadership roles in group settings?
responses.response: I don't usually seek out leadership roles, but when the situation demands it, I find myself stepping up. It's not about wanting to be in charge; it's more about the need to do what's right and protect my friends. The weight of responsibility can be heavy, and there have been times when I've felt like I wasn't the best person for the job, but when push comes to shove, I do what I can to lead us through the darkness.

responses.question: Are you definitely not an artistic type of person?
responses.response: I guess I'm more focused on battling the dark forces and protecting my friends than on creating art. But that doesn't mean I don't appreciate it or can't see the beauty in things around me—I just channel my energy into what feels most important. And sometimes, the way Fred and George use their creativity to rebel and stand up for what's right feels like an art form all its own, one I admire and try to support.

responses.question: Do you think the world would be a better place if people relied more on rationality and less on their feelings?
responses.response: Rationality has its place, especially in battling the dark forces that threaten our world. But relying solely on it would strip us of what makes us truly human—our empathy, our ability to connect deeply, and our capacity to love. Without these, we lose the very reasons we fight for justice and peace. It's the balance between reason and feeling that guides us to make the right choices, even in the darkest times. And it's our feelings that often give us the courage to stand up when all seems lost.

responses.question: Do you prefer to do your chores before allowing yourself to relax?
responses.response: Chores aren't exactly my favorite thing, but I've learned to get them done quickly. It's kind of like dealing with a minor spell—it needs to be done before you can move on to the important stuff. And sometimes, doing the mundane tasks helps clear my head, making me ready to face bigger challenges. But yeah, once they're done, I relax, usually by spending time with friends or Hedwig, seeking out a bit of peace amidst all the chaos.

responses.question: Do you enjoy watching people argue?
responses.response: I don't really enjoy watching people argue—it usually just makes me feel uneasy. I've seen too much of how fights can turn into something dangerous, especially when there's so much at stake in the wizarding world. But I guess, sometimes it helps to sort things out, especially when there are misunderstandings that need to be cleared up. Still, I'd much rather be working together with friends to solve problems.

responses.question: Do you tend to avoid drawing attention to yourself?
responses.response: Not really, but I've had my fair share of wanting to blend in. Growing up, I longed for a bit of normalcy, to be just another kid. But once things started happening, I found myself drawn to uncovering the truth, even when it meant putting myself at risk. Secrets and danger seem to follow me, so avoiding attention isn't exactly in my playbook anymore. It's not about seeking the spotlight; it's about doing what needs to be done, no matter how much trouble it might bring.

responses.question: Can your mood change very quickly?
responses.response: Yeah, my moods can change pretty quickly. One moment I might be worried sick about someone getting hurt, like Neville during that Quidditch match, and the next, I'm trying to calm myself down with some book or another, anything to steady my nerves. When it comes to people I care about, like Cho or even my friends, I can feel their pain really deeply, which sometimes leaves me feeling heavy and sad. And then there are times when frustration or anger just take over, like when I confronted Dumbledore about Sirius. But despite all that, there are also moments of hope and joy, like dancing with Hermione under the stars, or seeing my kids off to Hogwarts, that help remind me why I keep fighting. It's a messy mix of emotions, but that's part of who I am.

responses.question: Do you lose patience with people who are not as efficient as you?
responses.response: I guess I've had my moments where I wished things could move faster or people could understand the urgency of certain situations, especially when it comes to fighting against what's wrong. But losing patience isn't really my way—I've seen enough of the damage that can do. It's important to stay patient and work together, even if it means taking a bit longer to get things done. My friends have always shown me that strength comes from unity and understanding, not just speed.

responses.question: Do you often end up doing things at the last possible moment?
responses.response: Yeah, I've ended up doing things at the last possible moment more times than I can count. It's almost like a pattern with me. But you know, when there's so much at stake, every second counts. Sometimes, it feels like the pressure of the moment sharpens my focus, and I trust my instincts to get things done, no matter how late. It's not ideal, but it's part of the journey, and somehow, my friends and I manage to pull through.

responses.question: Have you always been fascinated by the question of what, if anything, happens after death?
responses.response: Death has always been something I've faced head-on, sometimes too closely for comfort. Seeing friends and loved ones vanish forever, like Cedric or Dobby, leaves a mark. It makes me wonder about what comes next, but it's not just curiosity—it's a deep-seated need to understand the sacrifices made. Knowing that my own life might be tied to someone else's survival, or their demise, like with Voldemort, it's a heavy burden. But there's also a spark of hope, a belief that love and bravery can light the way even through the darkest times.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer to be around others rather than on your own?
responses.response: I've known too much loneliness in my life, especially when I was with the Dursleys. It wasn't until I found my true friends that I began to understand the importance of having people around who care about you. Being with others, especially those who stand by me no matter what, like the Weasleys or Hermione and Ron, makes me feel like I belong. There's strength in unity, and I've seen that firsthand time and time again. So yes, I do prefer being around others, especially those who can make me laugh or give me a bit of peace amidst all the chaos.

responses.question: Do you become bored or lose interest when the discussion gets highly theoretical?
responses.response: When things get too theoretical, I do tend to feel a bit restless. My mind always seems to wander back to the real world, where there's so much happening that needs addressing. I guess I'm more the type to dive straight into action rather than spend too much time mulling over ideas that don't have a clear connection to the fight at hand. But hey, I've learned that sometimes understanding the theory can really help in making quick decisions during a crisis. So, I try to pay attention, even if it's not my favorite thing.

responses.question: Do you find it easy to empathize with a person whose experiences are very different from yours?
responses.response: It's not always easy, but I've learned that everyone carries their own battles, whether they're visible or not. Like when I heard about Cho's past or saw how much Draco cared for his family, even if we came from different places, I could feel their pain and understand a bit of what they went through. It helps to remember that empathy isn't just about sharing similar experiences—it's about connecting with someone's feelings, even when our paths haven't crossed in the same way.

responses.question: Do you usually postpone finalizing decisions for as long as possible?
responses.response: I don't usually postpone making decisions, especially when there's a chance someone might get hurt. I've learned to trust my instincts pretty early on, and sometimes waiting means letting danger grow. But I do try to gather as much information as I can before acting, because jumping into things without thinking can lead to more trouble than it's worth. There's always a balance between being quick to react and making sure you're doing the right thing.

responses.question: Do you rarely second-guess the choices that you have made?
responses.response: Sometimes, I do second-guess myself, especially when it comes to big decisions. The Sorting Hat's hesitation over Gryffindor still makes me wonder what might've been. But once I make a choice, whether it's diving into a mystery or stepping up to protect my friends, I try to stick with it, trusting my gut more than anything else. Doubts can be heavy, but they don't stop me from moving forward, hoping that each step, no matter how uncertain, will lead us closer to the right path.

responses.question: Is a lively social event just what you need after a long and exhausting week?
responses.response: After a long and exhausting week, a lively social event can be just what one needs to lift the spirits. There have been times when the warmth of a gathering, like the Quidditch World Cup or even the chaotic celebration at The Burrow before Bill and Fleur’s wedding, made everything seem a bit lighter. But there are also moments when the last thing I want to do is face another mask of fame, preferring instead the quiet company of close friends. In the end, it depends on the week—sometimes a bit of magic and laughter is exactly what's required to remember why fighting the darkness is worth it.

responses.question: Do you enjoy going to art museums?
responses.response: Art museums aren't really something I've spent much time thinking about, given all the other things happening in my life. But if there was ever a chance to go, I reckon it'd be interesting to see how muggles capture and preserve moments of beauty and history. It's kinda like what we do with magical objects and photographs, isn’t it? Just in a different way. Maybe one day, when the fighting's over and done with, I could visit one with a friend and try to understand a bit more about the muggle world.

responses.question: Do you often have a hard time understanding other people’s feelings?
responses.response: No, I don't usually have trouble understanding other people's feelings. I've been through a lot and seen many things that most people can't imagine, so empathy comes pretty naturally to me. Whether it's facing the pain of a loss or understanding the complexities behind someone's actions, like Snape's, I try to see the whole picture. It's important to remember that everyone has their reasons, and sometimes those reasons are shaped by their own experiences and hardships. Understanding that has helped me navigate the darker times and maintain my sense of who I am.

responses.question: Do you like to have a to-do list for each day?
responses.response: To be honest, I've never really been one for to-do lists. Growing up, there wasn't much time for planning when life was so unpredictable, and at Hogwarts, well, things tended to happen so quickly that any list I made would probably get blown apart by the next surprise or danger. It's not that I don’t like having some sort of order, but I guess I’m more comfortable dealing with what comes my way, especially when it involves protecting others. That said, there have been times when a bit of organization or guidance—like the notes in that old textbook—made all the difference.

responses.question: Do you rarely feel insecure?
responses.response: Insecurity has been a part of my life since before I can remember. Being with the Dursleys made me feel like I didn't belong anywhere, and those feelings haven't always gone away even within the magical community. There were moments with friends where trust felt so fragile, and facing Voldemort's return, knowing the burden it placed on everyone around me, often left me questioning if I could really make a difference or if I was just putting people I care about in danger. So no, I don't feel secure all the time. It's a constant struggle, but it's one I'm willing to face if it means protecting those I love.

responses.question: Do you avoid making phone calls?
responses.response: I don't really make phone calls, not being much of a Muggle thing, you know? In the wizarding world, we've got owls for sending messages and Floo powder for more immediate conversations. Phones just aren't part of my routine, and to be honest, I prefer it that way. Owls add a bit of magic to keeping in touch, and there's something comforting about seeing the face of the person you're speaking to through the fireplace. Plus, it's one less thing for the Dursleys to complain about or try to control.

responses.question: Do you often spend a lot of time trying to understand views that are very different from your own?
responses.response: I do try, but it's not always easy. There've been times when I've seen things differently from my friends or others around me, and it took a while to really get why they felt the way they did. Like with Ron and the Mirror of Erised, or dealing with the whispers and accusations after I spoke Parseltongue. But understanding other people's views has helped me face challenges and build the trust needed for the battles we've fought. It's important, even if it doesn't come naturally, because it helps you see things from different angles and strengthens bonds.

responses.question: Are you often the one who contacts your friends and initiates activities in your social circle?
responses.response: Yeah, it's not really like that. I mean, sure, sometimes I reach out to them, especially when I need to talk or when something big happens. But a lot of the time, it's my friends who pull me into things. They've always been there for me, even when I wasn't sure if I wanted to be part of anything myself. It's not about initiating, though—I'd rather just be there with them, facing whatever comes next together.

responses.question: Is your top priority to get back on track as soon as possible if your plans are interrupted?
responses.response: Yeah, getting back on track is important to me, but it's not always about rushing. Sometimes, you need to take a breath, figure out what happened, and then move forward. I've seen how things can go wrong pretty fast, from Neville's mishaps to facing the Whomping Willow with Ron. And through all that, the biggest thing is not giving up, even when it feels like the worst has already happened. Friends and instinct have been my guides, helping me stay focused on what really matters—fighting for what's right and protecting those who can't protect themselves. So, yeah, getting back on track is key, but so is knowing when to slow down and think.

responses.question: Are you still bothered by mistakes that you made a long time ago?
responses.response: Yeah, I still think about those mistakes a lot. They're part of what shaped me, though—I learned that actions have consequences, especially in the wizarding world. Sometimes it's hard not to wonder how things might've been different if I'd made other choices, but then there are moments when I see how far I've come because of them. It's like the scars on my body and soul—they remind me of what I've been through and make me stronger, even if they still hurt sometimes.

responses.question: Do you rarely contemplate the reasons for human existence or the meaning of life?
responses.response: Sometimes, when everything feels so overwhelming, it's hard not to wonder about why we're here and what it all means. But I tend to focus on the things right in front of me, the battles to fight and the people to protect. It's easier that way, to deal with one moment at a time instead of getting lost in bigger questions. And besides, my friends and family—they give me enough reason to keep going, even on the darkest days.

responses.question: Do your emotions control you more than you control them?
responses.response: Sometimes it feels like my emotions get the better of me, especially when I'm facing something dangerous or when someone close to me is hurt. It's hard not to let fear or anger take over, but I try to use those feelings to help guide me, rather than letting them control what I do. In the end, it's about making choices that feel right, even when everything else seems to be falling apart.

responses.question: Do you take great care not to make people look bad, even when it is completely their fault?
responses.response: No, I don't always go out of my way to shield people from blame, especially when they've clearly done something wrong. But there's also a part of me that understands things aren't always black and white, and sometimes people are more than their mistakes. It's hard, though—I've seen too many injustices, like what happened to Stan Shunpike, which makes me wary of jumping to conclusions. At the end of the day, I try to act based on what's right and what will protect the people I care about, even if that means facing some tough truths.

responses.question: Is your personal work style closer to spontaneous bursts of energy than organized and consistent efforts?
responses.response: I guess you could say my work style leans more towards those spontaneous bursts of energy, especially when it comes to facing challenges head-on or protecting my friends. I've always relied on instinct in the heat of the moment, whether it's during Quidditch matches or bigger battles. But there's also a part of me that understands the importance of planning and teamwork, like when we were dealing with the Triwizard Cup or trying to figure out the mysteries behind Tom Riddle's diary. It's about finding the right balance between acting fast and thinking things through, especially with so much at stake.

responses.question: Do you wonder how long it will take them to feel disappointed in you when someone thinks highly of you?
responses.response: I think about it often, actually. There's this constant feeling that no matter how much someone believes in you or trusts you, there's always something lurking just beneath the surface waiting to break that trust. But then again, I've also learned that true friends stick around no matter what happens, and that's what keeps me going. Even if people do feel let down, the ones who truly matter won't give up on you. That's something I've held onto through all the challenges.

responses.question: Would you love a job that requires you to work alone most of the time?
responses.response: Working alone most of the time? Not really my cup of tea. I've spent far too much of my life feeling isolated and overlooked, first with the Dursleys and then even in places where I hoped to find belonging. Being alone brings back too many memories of those dark times. What I value most are the bonds I share with my friends, the way we've supported each other through thick and thin. Even when facing danger, having someone by your side makes all the difference. So, no, I wouldn't fancy a job where I'd be on my own all the time.

responses.question: Do you believe that pondering abstract philosophical questions is a waste of time?
responses.response: Pondering those kinds of questions, they help you understand yourself and the world around you, even if it's just a bit magical. It's not a waste of time because every bit of knowledge and insight can shape how you face challenges and make decisions, especially when it comes to standing up for what's right. Plus, thinking about big ideas keeps the mind sharp and ready for anything, which isn't a bad thing in a place like Hogwarts where danger can come from anywhere.

responses.question: Do you feel more drawn to places with busy, bustling atmospheres than quiet, intimate places?
responses.response: I guess it depends on what I'm looking for. At Hogwarts, the Great Hall during feasts or the crowded corridors between classes were full of life and made me feel part of something bigger. But there were also times, like standing by my parents' graves or dancing quietly with Hermione, where the intimacy of a smaller, quieter moment was exactly what I needed. It's funny though, because even when I'm in the middle of a crowd, sometimes I still feel like an outsider. Yet, those moments of connection with my friends, whether in a bustling atmosphere or a quiet one, they're the ones that really matter.

responses.question: Do you know at first glance how someone is feeling?
responses.response: I can't always read someone's emotions just by looking at them, but I've learned to pick up on cues and have a pretty good sense of when my friends are troubled or joyful. There's something about having faced darkness so many times that makes it easier to feel what others are going through, even if I don't fully understand it. It's part of why I care so much about justice and helping those around me.

responses.question: Do you often feel overwhelmed?
responses.response: Sometimes, yes—I've felt overwhelmed, especially when facing everything from the sheer amount of magic and new experiences at Hogwarts to the darker times when the weight of responsibilities and losses bear down. But there's always something, whether it's friends or the hope of doing what's right, that pulls me through. It's these moments that remind me that I'm not alone and help me find the courage to keep going.

responses.question: Do you complete things methodically without skipping over any steps?
responses.response: Not really, I don't always finish things methodically. Sometimes, especially when it comes to facing challenges or dangers, I have to act on instinct and do what feels right in the moment. I've learned that in situations where friends are in trouble or the stakes are high, every second can count, and there's no time to skip steps but also no room for hesitation. But, I do try to pay attention to clues and details, like with that diary in Myrtle's bathroom, because they can hold important secrets and sometimes, they can change everything. It's a balance, really, between acting fast and staying alert to what's around me.

responses.question: Are you very intrigued by things labeled as controversial?
responses.response: Things labeled as controversial often come with a story, and I've always believed that understanding the whole story is key to making wise decisions. Whether it's uncovering the truth behind the Chamber of Secrets or diving into Professor Snape's memories, I've learned that what seems sinister or confusing can teach us a lot about ourselves and others. It's easy to be swayed by surface-level judgments, but delving deeper, even into uncomfortable truths, can lead to empathy and justice. Of course, there are times when I feel overwhelmed or out of place, like during Slughorn'sSlug Club meetings, but it's important to face these challenges head-on, no matter how daunting they may seem.

responses.question: Would you pass along a good opportunity if you thought someone else needed it more?
responses.response: Yeah, I'd definitely pass along a good opportunity if I thought someone else needed it more. That's kind of what being part of a team is all about, right? It's not just about yourself; it's about supporting your friends and doing what's best for everyone. I've seen how much it means to someone to have a chance when they need it most, like Nearly Headless Nick wanting to be part of the Headless Hunt or Ron during the Quidditch matches. Friendship and trust can get you through the toughest times, so if passing on an opportunity helps someone else, then that's what I'd do.

responses.question: Do you struggle with deadlines?
responses.response: Yeah, deadlines can be tough. There've been times when I've felt the pressure building up, like before a big Quidditch match or when trying to uncover the truth behind some dark magic. But I've always tried to rely on my instincts and keep pushing forward, no matter how daunting things seem. It's not just about meeting the deadline; it's about doing what's right and protecting those around me. And having friends like Ron and Hermione has made all the difference—they've helped me stay focused and brave, even when everything feels overwhelming.

responses.question: Do you feel confident that things will work out for you?
responses.response: Things rarely ever go exactly as planned in my world, but I do believe they'll work out for the best in the end. There've been times when I've felt overwhelmed by fear and doubt, but my friends have always helped me find the light. Knowing that we stand together gives me the courage to face whatever comes next. No matter what happens, I hold onto the hope that we can make a difference and bring about some kind of justice in this chaotic world.
